titles.title: Kyoushoku Soukou Guyver (2005)
Guyver tv
強殖装甲ガイバー (2005)
Guyver: The Bioboosted Armor
Guyver - The Bioboosted Armor
Guyver (2005)
มนุษย์เกราะชีวะ

recommendations.recommendation:
a really good anime, but unfortunately when things get really interesting it ends.
just another Anime with broken ending.

The self-description of this series dosn`t do it justice, as it sounds like something that is going to be cheezy and weak, however that isn`t the case at all. Best Shounen i have seen! Highly recommended!

As good as the OVAs and even better. Too bad that they didn`t keep the OST, but the story is more detailed, more character development and plot was covered. The only negative thing about TV series is that it ends right in the middle of something great, like Berserk. The story has so much potential that it saddens me that there`s no sequel yet.

anime.description: Things get out of control at the Chronos syndicate and three of their secret experimental G-units are stolen. They dispatch a special combat unit of biobeast soldiers with instructions to recover the units at all costs. They are able to recover one of the devices. A normal high school student, Fukamachi Sho finds and activates the 2nd device, which transforms him into Guyver, a powerful living suit of Bioboosted Armour. And the 3rd device strangely goes missing.

tag.name: shounen
tag.description: In the context of manga and associated media, shounen, literally meaning "youth" and often also specifically "boy", refers to a male audience roughly between the ages of 10 and 18. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: super power
tag.description: Be it an ancient Greek Heracles, a cybernetic muscle-man, or a fourteen year-old girl in a mini-skirted sailor suit. As long as they have super powers, they`re in the show.

tag.name: present
tag.description: Somewhere between past and future.

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: power suit
tag.description: Power Suits are similar to Piloted Robots which are controlled from inside the robot except that Power Suits tend to be more directly tied to how the character moves and they are usually not as big as Piloted Robots can be. They are still mechanical and shouldn`t be confused with plug suits.

tag.name: dark fantasy
tag.description: Focus set on darker themes in a fantasy setting, sometimes leaning towards horror elements. Bleak and pessimistic tones often dominate. Dark supernatural beings like vampires may play a significant role.

tag.name: parasite
tag.description: Parasites are life forms that feed off other beings in some way. In anime, they are often aliens and usually intelligent. For shock value, and to avoid having to draw aliens all the time, their prey is preferably human; they may see humans as food, as puppets for mind control, or simply as temporary body hosts. In every case, the human is the victim of a "merging", which is not to be confused with the more "amicable" symbiosis.

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse. See also http://anidb.net/t6493 [manhua] and http://anidb.net/t5010 [manhwa].

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: fantasy
tag.description: Fantasy is a genre of fiction that uses magic and other supernatural phenomena as a primary element of plot, theme, or setting. Many works within the genre take place in fictional worlds where magic is common. Fantasy is generally distinguished from science fiction and horror by the expectation that it steers clear of (pseudo-)scientific and macabre themes, respectively, though there is a great deal of overlap between the three (which are subgenres of speculative fiction). In popular culture, the genre of fantasy is dominated by its medievalist form, especially since the worldwide success of The Lord of the Rings books by J. R. R. Tolkien. In its broadest sense however, fantasy comprises works by many writers, artists, filmmakers, and musicians, from ancient myths and legends to many recent works embraced by a wide audience today. Fantasy is a vibrant area of academic study in a number of disciplines (English, cultural studies, comparative literature, history, medieval studies). Work in this area ranges widely, from the structuralist theory of Tzvetan Todorov, which emphasizes the fantastic as a liminal space, to work on the connections (political, historical, literary) between medievalism and popular culture Source: Wiki

tag.name: horror
tag.description: The horror cinematic genre is characterized by the attempt to make the viewer experience dread, fear, terror, or horror. Often their plots involve the intrusion of an evil force, event or personage, sometimes of supernatural origin, on the mundane world and the consequences thereof.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: conspiracy
tag.description: The conspiracy thriller (or paranoid thriller) is a sub-genre of the thriller which flourished in the 1970s in the US (and was echoed in other parts of the world) in the wake of a number of high-profile scandals and controversies (most notably Vietnam, the assassination of President Kennedy, Chappaquiddick and Watergate), and which exposed what many people regarded as the clandestine machinations and conspiracies beneath the orderly fabric of political life. The protagonists of conspiracy thrillers are often journalists or amateur investigators who find themselves (often inadvertently) pulling on a small thread which unravels a vast conspiracy that ultimately goes "all the way to the top".

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: mythology
tag.description: The anime gets inspirations from many forms of mythologies (either Greek, Egyptian, Nord, etc.) to form its story and setting.

tag.name: Greek mythology
tag.description: The anime is derived or draws elements from the Greek mythology, and as such features some mythological characteristics of Ancient Greece. Those may be creatures, such as the Centaur or Hydra, tales, such as that of the Trojan War, or even the Gods themselves, like Zeus or Poseidon. More subtle references also count, such as the careful usage of names of places or people that hold significance in the myths.

tag.name: incomplete story
tag.description: The show does not cover all of the original work (if present) or was cancelled prematurely, leaving plot lines unresolved or aborting character development. Sometimes the show runs through all its initially slotted episodes and adapts all of the original work (if applicable) but fails to present a proper ending, leaving viewers wondering whether they`re missing the final episodes. In some cases, this may overlap with the studio forging an anime-original ending. Such an ending normally manages to allow the show to "finish", but may still suffer from incomplete story issues. An incomplete storyline is not to be confused with the sequel bait, which is when the story presented by the show is finished but leaves enough room for a sequel to be produced. Sometimes this goes as far as to present a new potential problem in the last few minutes; that is usual for after-credits footage in movies.

tag.name: ending tags that need merging
tag.description: See also: http://anidb.net/post426253 [http://anidb.net/post426253] and http://anidb.net/c6774745 [http://anidb.net/c6774745]

tag.name: ancient aliens
tag.description: Ancient aliens, hundreds, thousands, or millions of years in the past; aliens from another world or dimension played a significant role in human history. Pictured: http://anidb.net/a40 [Nadia: The Secret of The Blue Water / Fushigi no Umi no Nadia]

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Fukamachi Shou
character.description: Fukamachi Shou is main protagonist of the series. A 17 years old, second-year student at a Tokyo-area high school, Shou cares deeply for Segawa Mizuki and has a romantic interest in her. Tetsuro Segawa, Mizuki`s older brother, is his closest friend. He comes across the mysterious Guyver unit, which merges with him and takes form as "Guyver I." Chronos is now in pursuit of Shou, wanting the return of the Guyver unit. Now, Shou must fight for his life and protect those close to him against the Zoanoids of Chronos.

character.name: Guyver I
character.description: Guyver One is Sho Fukamachi , an ordinary high school student, who was merged with a bio-booster symbiont completely by accident. Chronos has attempted anything in their power to get the bio-weapon back... and thus turned Guyver One into one of their most deadly enemies. Although Guyver One is probably the least powerful Guyver due to the nature of its host as it can be assumed that all Guyver Units have the same power levels so differences between them come predominantly from their Hosts, he is nevertheless a formidable opponent. He is also the warrior who succesfully merged with a Creator-ship, and as a result created the Gigantic upgrade. This alone makes him unique.

character.name: Segawa Mizuki
character.description: Mizuki is a typical school girl that goes to the same school as Shou. She is the younger sister of Tetsuro Segawa, Shou Fukamachi`s best friend. At first, she grows a crush on Agito Makishima, but later starts to appreciate Shou a lot more, to the point where her affections have completely shifted over to him.

character.name: Segawa Tetsuro
character.description: Tetsuro is a chubby third-year student and is Shou`s closest friend. He is highly intelligent, keeps his hair cut short and wears glasses. Tetsuro is a Science Fiction fan and the leader of the Sci-Fi society club in the school, which gives him some knowledge to make quite a few assumptions about the things involving the Guyver.

character.name: Makishima Agito
character.description: Agito is a third-year student at the same high school the others attend. He almost never allows sentiment to stand in his way. He doesn`t even show much expression in his face, but acts quite friendly at school. He finds a Guyver unit and merges with it to become "Guyver III." Agito also seems to have extensive knowledge on the Guyver and its abilities and exhibits them quite well. Agito seems to have his own agenda when it comes to dealing with Chronos. He is an excellent example of an anti-hero.

character.name: Guyver III
character.description: Guyver Three is Agito Makishima , also a high school student, although of a higher class than Fukamachi. Unlike the other Guyvers, he merged with the final bio-booster symbiont deliberately. This move suits his personality, which craves power above anything else as he called himself Zeus to Chronos for he would take their Throne. He is the deadliest surviving Guyver, partly because his greater willpower enabled him to take control of the Gigantic unit from Fukamachi to merge with it himself, to become the deadliest warrior the world has ever seen: the Gigantic Dark. Deadly; yes, humane; questionable.

character.name: Makishima Genzou
character.description: Genzou Makishima is the adoptive father of Agito Makishima and a high ranking member of Chronos. He eventually lost his position, as the head of Chronos Japan, after he lost the three G-Units and constantly failed to retrieve them.

episode.title: 驚異の強殖装甲
The Wondrous Bio-Boosted Armor
episode.summary: A young high school boy’s life is changed forever when he stumbles upon a mysterious Guyver unit. Upon activation, the unit merges with the boy to create Guyver I. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 秘密結社クロノス
The Secret Society of Chronos
episode.summary: Sho activates the Guyver unit in order to battle two Zoanoids sent by the Chronos Corporation. Elsewhere, the final Guyver unit merges with Inspector Risker. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 監察官リスカー
Inspector Risker
episode.summary: Chronos sends an entire troop of Zoanoids to apprehend Sho, who must unlock one of Guyver’s advanced weapons to escape. Unfortunately, Guyver II will not be so easy to defeat. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 黄昏の来訪者
The Visitor at Dusk
episode.summary: Risker and Sho face each other in an epic battle that puts their Guyver units to the test, and a new head of Chronos arrives in Japan with a newer, more powerful Zoanoid. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 第三の影
The Third Shadow
episode.summary: Sho and Tetsuro discover that the incident at their school is being classified as a terrorist attack by Chronos. After school, Sho is attacked by more Zoanoids. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 死闘の果てに...
Beyond the Desperate Battle
episode.summary: Guyot reveals his ultimate plan for recapturing the Guyver unit: a Zoanoid known as Enzyme. While searching for answers about the Guyver, Sho is attacked by Enzyme. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 奇跡の超細胞
The Miraculous Cell
Kiseki no Chousaibou
episode.summary: After Guyver I is destroyed by Enzyme, Tetsuro is taken captive by Chronos, and Guyot reveals his heinous plan to achieve total world domination! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 激震の摩天楼
Shuddering Skyscraper
Gekishin no Matenrou
episode.summary: The regenerated Guyver I continues to wreak havoc in Chronos, Guyver II battles Guyver III, and Guyot explains the “creators of mankind”. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 灰と追憶
Ash and Memories
episode.summary: Sho - already doubting his own existence - suffers the loss of his home in a brutal confrontation with a potent new Hyper-Zoanoid. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 追撃への序曲
Prelude to the Chase
episode.summary: Guyot reveals his new plan for capturing Guyver I, only to be suddenly attacked by Guyver III. Sho battles the Lost Number unit, but is unable to defeat them without help. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 遺跡基地
Relic`s Point
episode.summary: After his fight against the Lost Numbers unit, Sho infiltrates a Chronos base on a daring rescue mission, but he’ll need help from Guyver III to get everyone out alive. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: それぞれの決意
To Each His Own Resolution
episode.summary: Guyver I assists Guyver III in eluding a team of Elite Hyper-Zoanoids. During the battle, one of the Zoanoids abducts Sho’s father. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 悲劇のエンザイムII
The Tragic Enzyme II
episode.summary: Sho’s happy reunion with his father is spoiled by the shocking appearance of Enzyme II. Could this be the end of Guyver I? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 雨の逃避行
Escape in the Rain
episode.summary: Guyver III is overpowered by Enzyme II Zoanoids, Guyver I suffers an inopportune armor deactivation, and Murakami reveals the secrets of his past. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ギュオー出陣
Guyot Joins the Fray
episode.summary: Murakami continues his explanation of the origins of mankind and Guyvers. Later, Guyot somehow manages to locate the group and ruthlessly attacks them. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 甦れガイバーI
Arise, Guyver I
episode.summary: Sho and Mizuki are forced to take refuge in a cave, and Sho questions why is no longer capable of activating the Guyver. Can he handle the answer? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 悪夢の包囲網
Nightmarish Encirclement
episode.summary: Sho and Mizuki encounter a town inhabited by a many Zoanoids, but Sho is not interested in killing what used to be innocent people. Guyver III, on the other hand, has a different outlook. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 遺跡鳴動
Vibrations
episode.summary: Sho, Mizuki, and Agito make their way to the underground laboratory of a group of mutinous scientists, and Murakami attempts to heal himself through use of the “relic”. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 突入前夜
The Night Before the Final Assault
episode.summary: The twelve Zoalords meet to discuss Guyot, Mizuki worries about Sho’s fate, and preparation are made for entering the “relic”. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 降臨者の船
The Creators` Ship
episode.summary: One of the former Chronos scientists explains how the organization originally obtained the Guyver units, and Sho connects to the relic to learn more about the very first Guyver. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 混乱の遺跡基地
Relic`s Point in Disarray
episode.summary: Guyot and Archanfel face each other in battle. Archanfel is consistently able to deflect his enemy’s attacks, but Guyot has one final trick up his sleeve. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 崩壊のカウント・ダウン
Countdown to Collapse
episode.summary: Guyot uses a special attack to imprison Archanfel. Next, he begins an epic clash with Murakami. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 殲滅の光芒
Ray of Annihilation
episode.summary: Guyot inflicts great damage upon Murakami, Sho exits the relic, and Archanfel finally escapes his dark prison. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 制圧下の街で
In a Conquered Town
episode.summary: One year after X-Day, Chronos rules the world and Zoanoids comprise part of the population. Tetsuro and Mizuki live in hiding, doubting whether Sho is actually still alive. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 胎動の蛹
Quickening of the Chrysalis
episode.summary: Guyver III leads the Zeus Thunderbolt against the Chronos Coporation, and Sho makes a stunning sacrifice. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 降臨!! 巨人殖装
Come Forth, Gigantic!
episode.summary: The final showdown begins! A giant cocoon takes center stage, and Sho makes a desperate attempt to return home for good. Source: crunchyroll
